Description
Recent Event Highlights: Franklin Park area no longer Toledo's 'Rodeo Drive' - Toledo Blade, Retail vacancies grow in Shore shopping districts - Asbury Park Press, This Week in Retail: Empty 'Big Boxes' Showing Resiliency in Strong Markets - CoStar Group, Big Box Retail Users Eye Rebound - PR Newswire (press release), Big-box retailers leave huge spaces for Dallas brokers to fill - Dallas Morning News, Landlords Worry About Closures As Barnes&Noble Contemplates Alternatives - Retail Traffic, and 131 more...
Created by dipity on Nov 3, 2008
Last updated: 12/29/10 at 12:26 AM
Followers
Comments Please Join or Log In to comment.
Recent Events on Circuit City Store Closings

Source Info Brooklyn Eagle http://www.brooklyneagle.com/categories/category.php?category_id=5&id=37072 Jonathan Reckford, CEO, Habitat for Humanity May 4, 2010 7:14 AM Jonathan Reckford, CEO of Habitat for Humanity, spoke to an audience of MBA students at the Stanford Graduate School of Business as part of the View From The Top series. Jonathan (Stanford MBA, '89) shared his unique leadership perspective from his time as a senior executive in the private sector, to executive pastor of a Presbyterian church, and finally to his current role as CEO of a global religiously-based non-profit organization. Related Article: www.gsb.stanford.edu Smart Grid, Utilities, and Internet Protocols Apr 16, 2010 10:20 AM Google Tech Talk April 14, 2010 ABSTRACT Presented by Erich W. Gunther. The smart grid is a big topic these days, but before there was a smart grid newspaper headline, the utilities have been experimenting with TCP/IP in the backend networks for a while now. Erich Gunther of enernex (www.enernex.com) will present a reference model and concept of network operations for the power industry including how Internet Protocols fit in that space. Along the way he will touch on what has worked, what hasn't and some of the security issues along the way. Erich W. Gunther is the co-founder, chairman and chief technology officer for EnerNex Corporation - an electric power research, engineering, and consulting firm - located in Knoxville Tennessee. With 30 years of experience in the electric power industry, Erich is no stranger to smart grid - he has been involved in defining what smart grid is before the term itself was coined. Calif Unemployment at 16% Jun 9, 2009 2:32 PM we saw Christmas retail sales: womens apparel down 23%; home furnishings and electronics off 27%; luxury items down 35%. These are Depression Era collapses. We saw major bankruptcies, such as retailers Circuit City and Linens and Things. One bankruptcy after another. Then we saw store closings. Starbucks, Home D&D;Power and down the line. The question becomes who is going to take all of the vacant retail space? Who is going to rent it? The answer is nobody. Now we look at the financial collapse ... "Morning Piss" "Empty Economy" "out of business" closed "store closings" "Phil Sierra" recession "Circuit City ... Circuit City last days May 22, 2009 8:34 AM This is location 3254 Sugar Land, Texas. I worked for the company for 19 years. This was the last location I worked at the time the company shut down. I want to say thank you very much to eveyone I had the chance to meet and work with over 19 years. I will always remember the people and how the company was a great success at one time. It was a sad day at the end. I know we will all come thru the and be more successful in the future. This is just a chapter in life that has come to an end ... Sound Advice started America's Economy is in Need of a Change Apr 14, 2009 8:18 AM "From 1997 through 2007 consumer spending rose much faster than GDP and went from 67.0 percent to 71.6 percent of GDP. It was not because Americans were making more money or using their savings. It resulted from easy credit. First it was chiefly through credit cards. Then it was by refinancing home mortgages and through home equity loans; this was possible during a period of rising home values, which itself was driven by making money for mortgages far too easy. The first round of closings will conclude by March 1, and a federal bankruptcy court here has scheduled an auction for the stores' leases
Source Info TWICE http://www.twice.com/article/233933-Circuit_City_Store_Closings_Underway.php?rssid=20328 Tac Thunderbox AMP 28r GUTIARMANIA - Amp for Guitar Hero or Rock Band Feb 8, 2009 5:04 PM So I was meandering around Circuit City this afternoon looking at all the 30-50% off items before their final closing of their doors, and I found this little amplifier sitting on the bottom of the shelf in the store...
What is this thing but some goofey waste of an Amplifier created in attempt to market to people who play Guitar Hero or Rock Band. They basically stuck a pair of RCA audio inputs on a basic guitar/bass practice amp and called it a "gamer amp" or something like that.
Despite the apparently cheap quality of this amplifier, it actually sounds pretty good, even through a cheap $9 microphone like I'm using here to record it. My Zune also does not sound too bad through this thing either. Circuit City Going Out of Business Final Days Commercial Feb 5, 2009 3:01 PM "Circuit City would like to thank all of the customers who have shopped with us over the past 60 years. Unfortunately, we announced on January 16, 2009, that we are going out of business." - http://www.circuitcity.com/closed.html A Circut City Tribute Feb 2, 2009 11:17 AM Here is a tribute to all Circuit City stores that are closing. Go get the sales while they last. Looks like the economy has taken down another store, well thats it for Circuit City.
